title: Lamprais
text:
Lumprice () is a <a href="Cuisine%20of%20Sri%20Lanka">Sri Lankan</a> dish that was introduced by the country's <a href="Dutch%20Burghers">Dutch Burgher</a> population. Lumprice is an Anglicised derivative of the Dutch word "lomprijst", which loosely translated means a packet or lump of rice.
History.
From 1658 until 1796, Sri Lanka was under <a href="Dutch%20people">Dutch</a> rule. The <a href="Dutch%20Burghers">Dutch Burghers</a> (an ethnic group of mixed Dutch, <a href="Portuguese%20Burghers">Portuguese Burghers</a> and Sri Lankan descent) came up with this delicacy. The dish itself is not a native dish to the Netherlands but is based on the <a href="Indonesian%20cuisine">Javanese meal</a>, <a href="Lemper">Lemper</a>. Lemper is a snack consisting of shredded seasoned meat, <a href="glutinous%20rice">glutinous rice</a> wrapped in a banana leaf. The Dutch in <a href="Dutch%20Ceylon">Dutch Ceylon</a> are likely to have adapted this dish from the <a href="Dutch%20East%20Indies">Dutch East Indies</a> in the early 16th Century.
One of the first literary mentions of Lamprais was in Hilda Deutrom's "Ceylon Daily News Cookery Book", published in 1929.
Composition.
It consists of two special <a href="curries">curries</a> (a three meat curry, often including beef, pork and chicken - and ash <a href="Cooking%20banana">plantain</a> with <a href="aubergine">aubergine</a>), seeni <a href="Sambal%23Sri%20Lankan%20sambal">sambal</a>, <a href="shrimp%20paste">belacan</a>, <a href="frikadeller">frikadeller</a> meatballs and <a href="rice">rice</a> boiled in stock, all of which is wrapped in <a href="Banana%20leaf">banana leaves</a> and baked in an oven. The rice is made by frying raw short grain rice with onions and spices in butter or ghee and then cooking it in a meat stock. A hard boiled egg which has been deep-fried is also a common, but non-traditional, addition.
The traditional recipe always contains three meat items however modern versions can include just a single meat, such as fish or chicken or as a vegetarian version.
